block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. Tomorrow from noon to 5 p.m., Kwaanza celebrations, including performances, visual and performing arts workshops and a film festival. The Hall of Ocean Life will be transformed to an African village with a marketplace. The annual origami tree is on display during the holidays. Museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children 2 to 12; under 2, free. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' Tickets: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children under 12. In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. Visitors can buy a First Night New York City 2001 Button, $10 for adults, $5 for children (2 to 12), for free admission into the museum Sunday. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. Today from 1 to 2:30 p.m., doll and teddy bear parade; children should bring one favorite doll or teddy bear. Prepaid reservations required: $7 a child. Sunday from 8 p.m. to 1 a.m., New Year's Eve Cotillion, with dress in 19th-century style; costume optional; singles welcome. Prepaid reservations required: $5 a person. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly, children 6 to 18 and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Sunday night, from 7 to 12:30, New Year's Eve celebration, including music, dance lessons, comedy acts and midnight fireworks. There will also be activities for youngsters in Fisher Gallery at 7:30 and 8:30. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. Visitors can buy a First Night New York City 2001 Button, $10 for adults, $5 for children (2 to 12), for free admission into the museum on Sunday and for the New Year's Eve celebration. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. Monday from 3 to 6 p.m., a New Year's Day reception, including guided tours of the house and Champagne punch. Reservations required: $20; $10 for members. Tours, Saturdays and Sundays; a self-guided tour is available on weekdays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; members, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. ''Guys and Dolls,'' an exhibition celebrating the 50th anniversary of the original Broadway production, including photographs, drawings, prints and memorabilia; through June 10. Today at 2 p.m., a screening of Norman Jewison's ''40 Pounds of Trouble'' (1963), a remake of ''Little Miss Marker,'' the 1934 film based on a Damon Runyon story. ''A Portfolio of New York, 1894-97: 12 Views by Edwin Davis French''; through March 18. ''Painting the Town: Cityscapes of New York''; through Dec. 31, 2002. ''Life of the People: Realist Prints and Drawings From the Ben and Beatrice Goldstein Collection, 1912-48''; through Jan. 14. Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed Mondays. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130. Visitors can buy a First Night New York City 2001 Button, $10 for adults, $5 for children (2 to 12), for free admission into the museum Sunday. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: www.nycmillennium.org or (212) 676-2000.

WORLD FINANCIAL CENTER, North Bridge, 200 Liberty Street, between West and Vesey Streets, Lower Manhattan. ''Festival of Light and Sound,'' featuring 100,000 lights strung among the 50-foot palm trees throughout the vaulted glass atrium of the Winter Garden, through Monday. Free. Information: (212) 945-0505.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Circle Line's New Year's Eve Cruise, including hors d'oeuvres, open bar, Champagne toast and midnight fireworks. Boarding begins at 9:30 p.m.; sailing from 10 p.m. to 1 a.m. Reservations required; $100 a person. Information: (212) 563-3200.

HOLIDAY FAMILY CRUISES, Spirit Cruises, Pier 61, Chelsea Piers, 23rd Street and the West Side Highway. Today from 3 to 5:30 p.m. and Sunday from 1 to 3:30 p.m., a cruise down the Hudson River including lunch, music and dancing. The Sunday cruise includes a New Year's toast. Tickets, $41.95; $31.95 for children 3 to 11; under 3, free. Information and reservations: (212) 727-2789.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Three-hour New Year's Eve cruise, including a five-course dinner, open bar, midnight fireworks and dancing; complimentary split of Champagne for each couple. The cruse begins boarding at 9 p.m., and sails from 10 p.m. to 1 a.m., and the party continues at dockside until 1:30 a.m.; $225 a person, plus tax and gratuities. Reservations are required. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $79.13; Saturdays, $83.46; Sundays, $70.47 (does not include beverages or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $43.71; children 12 and under, $23.43. Information: (212) 630-8100.
RECREATION

RUNNER'S WORLD/ASICS MIDNIGHT RUN, Central Park. A four-mile run that starts at 72nd Street Transverse at Bethesda Terrace. A masquerade parade will precede the race at 10:45 p.m. at the 72nd Street Band Shell. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $30; $25 for club members. Race-day registration, $35; $30 for members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
EVENTS

NEW YEAR'S EVE IN TIMES SQUARE. At about 6:05 p.m. on Sunday the New Year's Eve ball will be lighted and raised. Confetti, pompoms and balloons will be distributed beginning at 10 p.m. At 11 p.m. giant puppets representing Father Time and Baby Time will move through the crowd. At 11:59 the ball will begin its descent, accompanied by pyrotechnics at midnight. Free.
ROCKEFELLER CENTER CHRISTMAS TREE. On view through Wednesday. Lights are on daily, 5:30 a.m. to 11:30 p.m.

''A CHRISTMAS CAROL,'' Madison Square Garden, a musical based on the Dickens story, with Frank Langella. Today at 2 and 7:30 p.m.; tomorrow at 1 and 5 p.m.; Sunday at 2 p.m. Through Sunday. Tickets: $29 to $90. Information: (212) 307-4111.

''CHRISTMAS SPECTACULAR,'' Radio City Music Hall, 1260 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street. The annual holiday show with the Rockettes. Today at 10:30 a.m. and 1, 3:30, 6:30 and 9 p.m.; tomorrow at 9 and 11:30 a.m. and 2, 4:30, 7:30 and 10 p.m.; Sunday at 11 a.m. Through Jan. 7. Some shows are sold out. Tickets: $32 to $80. Information: (212) 307-1000 or (212) 247-4777.

''CLOWN AROUND TOWN,'' Big Apple Circus, Lincoln Center. The 23rd production of the one-ring circus. Today, tomorrow and Monday at 12:30 and 4:30 p.m.; Sunday at 12:30 and 9:30 p.m. (Special New Year's Eve performance; tickets, $40 to $125; half-price for children under 12.) Tickets, $18 to $62. Through Jan. 7. Information: (800) 922-3772; tickets, (212) 721-6500 or (212) 307-4100.

''BARNUM'S KALEIDOSCAPE,'' Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas at 40th Street. Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey's first circus under a tent in 45 years. Today at 2 and 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 3:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 1 p.m. Through Sunday. Tickets, $20 to $75. Information: (877) 922-7686.
GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL HOLIDAY FAIR AND LASER LIGHT SHOW. Daily laser light shows every half-hour from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. through Sunday. Information: (212) 340-2210.

''A STRONGER SOUL WITHIN A FINER FRAME: PORTRAYING AFRICAN-AMERICANS IN THE BLACK RENAISSANCE,'' Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem. A free exhibition of books, posters, photographs and recordings from the Archie Givens Sr. Collection of African-American Literature at the University of Minnesota Libraries. Through Jan. 16. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 531-5300.

AMOR ARTIS CHORUS AND BAROQUE ORCHESTRA will perform an all-Bach concert on Sunday night at 8 at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 76th Street and Lexington Avenue. Tickets, $30 for reserved seats; $25 for general admission. Information and reservations: (212) 874-4513.

ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S HOLIDAY CONCERTS, Sunday night at 7, John Eliot Gardiner, the Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists finish their goal of performing all of Bach's cantatas in the course of the year 2000. Tickets, $30 to $150. Reservations: (212) 307-7171. At 11 p.m., an organ concert by William K. Trafka featuring his transcription of Aaron Copland's ''Fanfare for the Common Man,'' the premiere of David Conte's ''Recollection'' and works by Bach. Free. St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 51st Street. Information: (212) 378-0244.

''BRONX FIRST NIGHT,'' Crotona Park, 1700 Fulton Street, at 173rd Street. On Sunday, from 7 p.m. to 12:20 a.m., events including dancing, musical performances, face painting and storytelling at the Bathhouse and C.S. 4 in celebration of the New Year. Free with the purchase of a First Night 2001 Button: $10; $5 for children (2 to 12). Buttons can be purchased at the City Store in the Manhattan Municipal Building, 1 Centre Street, and the Times Square Visitors Center, Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

''BROOKLYN FIRST NIGHT,'' Grand Army Plaza, Prospect Park. Sunday night at 10, a New Year's Eve street party with a D.J., giant puppets, street performers and fireworks. Admission to the Prospect Park rink, zoo and special events at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn Museum of Art, Brooklyn Children's Museum and Brooklyn Public Library is free with the purchase of a First Night button, available at the rink, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Central Library in Grand Army Plaza or through Ticketmaster. First Night 2001 Buttons, $10; $5 for children (2 to 12). Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (718) 965-8999 or www.nycmillennium.org.

''MANHATTAN FIRST NIGHT,'' Central Park, Fifth Avenue at 62nd Street. Sunday night from 8 to 12:30, skating at Wollman Rink, fireworks at midnight, raffle contests and samba and capoeira shows. Additional activities throughout the borough include dancing, arts and crafts and circus performers at the MetLife Building, 200 Park Avenue; palm reading, comedy, live music and storytelling at the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum, Pier 86 at West 46th Street and 12th Avenue, Clinton; and concerts at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue; St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street; and the Second Church of Christ, Scientist, 10 West 68th Street, at Central Park West. Admission to these events is free with the purchase of a First Night 2001 Button. Admission, $10; $5 for children (2 to 12). Buttons can be purchased directly at the City Store in the Manhattan Municipal Building, 1 Centre Street, and the Times Square Visitors Center, Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

''QUEENS FIRST NIGHT,'' Unisphere, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Sunday night from 10 to 12:30, live music and fireworks will accompany this New Year's Eve celebration. Additional activities throughout the day will be held at the Queens Wildlife Conservancy, World's Fair Ice Skating Rink, New York Hall of Science, Queens Theater in the Park and Queens Museum of Art. Free with the purchase of a First Night 2001 Button: $10; $5 for children (2 to 12). Buttons can be purchased directly at the City Store in the Manhattan Municipal Building, 1 Centre Street, and the Times Square Visitor's Center, Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

''STATEN ISLAND FIRST NIGHT,'' Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, (718) 448-2500. Events in celebration of the New Year, Sunday night from 6 to midnight include dancing, ice sculpture demonstrations, musical performances and fireworks at midnight. Free with the purchase of a First Night 2001 Button: $10; $5 for children (2 to 12). Snug Harbor Cultural Center box office: (718) 815-7684. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

NATIONAL CHORALE AND ORCHESTRA will perform Johann Strauss' operetta ''Die Fledermaus'' at Avery Fisher Hall, Sunday night at 8. With Jon Garison and Jeffrey Renolds, tenors; Hanli Stapela and Joanna Mongiardo, sopranos; and Gigi Mitchell-Velasco, mezzo soprano. Tickets, $50 to $250. Information and reservations: (212) 333-5333 or (212) 721-6500.

NEW YEAR'S EVE CONCERT FOR PEACE, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Sunday night at 7:30, music and readings with Judy Collins, Linda Lavin, David Dinkins, Jason Robert Brown, Universes, Amy Burton, John Pizzareli, the Memorial Baptist Church Gospel Choir and the New Year's Eve Festival Orchestra and Chorus. Also, a statue of people whose accomplishments exemplified the 20th century will be unveiled. Tickets, $50 for reserved seats; general admission, free.

RIVERSIDE CHURCH NEW YEAR'S EVE SERVICE, 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street, Morningside Heights. Sunday night at 10:30. Timothy Smith, organist, will present an all-Bach recital followed by a service at 11 featuring the Riverside Choir and Brass Quartet. Free. Information: (212) 870-6722.

'' 'GLOBAL WARMING': THE ALTERNATIVE NEW YEAR'S DAY SPOKEN WORD PERFORMANCE EXTRAVAGANZA.'' CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, is the host of this eight-hour event featuring poets and performance artists on Monday from 4 p.m. to midnight. Canned goods will be collected, and problems associated with global warming will be addressed by staff members. Free. Information: (212) 982-4052.

''NEW YEAR'S DAY 2001 MARATHON READING,'' beginning at 2 p.m. on Monday and continuing past midnight, the Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church, at 10th Street and Second Avenue, East Village, will present more than 100 poets, musicians, dancers and artists performing and reading new works. Performers include Patti Smith, John Cale, Jim Caroll, Eric Bogosian, Penny Arcade, Lenny Kaye and others. Tickets, $15; $12 for students, the elderly and Project members. Information: (212) 674-0910.
WALKING TOURS

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area followed by dinner at Sylvia's restaurant and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 in front of Starbucks on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $55. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

''TIMES SQUARE AND HOW IT GOT THAT WAY.'' A tour of the area with emphasis on theater history, architecture, urban planning and commercialization. Meets today at 11 a.m. on the the northwest corner of 47th Street and Avenue of the Americas. Fee: $10; $8 for students, the elderly and members of the Municipal Art Society. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''HARLEM: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE.'' Explores the neighborhood's churches, residences and jazz clubs. Meets tomorrow at 3 p.m. on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.

''BROOKLYN BRIDGE WALK INTO THE NEW YEAR.'' Watch the fireworks and learn how the Roebling family built the Brooklyn Bridge. Meets Sunday night at 10:30 outside Blimpie's at 38 Park Row, between Spruce and Beekman Streets, across from City Hall Park, Lower Manhattan. Sponsored by Dr. Phil New York Talks and Walks. Fee: $20. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''NEW YEAR'S EVE JAUNT,'' Chinatown. Explores the history and culture of the largest Chinese community in the United States. Tour stops include a Chinese bakery and herbal shop, a Buddhist temple and the oldest row house in New York City. Optional dinner following the tour. Sunday at 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 p.m. Fee: $5 plus dinner. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 265-2663.

''NEW YEAR'S NEW WORLD'' includes a talk on the history of American immigration and a visit to the Ellis Island Museum. Meets Sunday at noon at the Immigrant Statue in front of Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $18; $16 for students and the elderly. Fee includes boat ticket and movie. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''NEW YEAR'S DAY HANGOVER TOUR,'' SoHo. Focuses on the neighborhood's buildings, restaurants and the history of its street names. Includes stops at the Puck Building, a Louis Sullivan skyscraper and the Old Mechant's House. Meets Monday at 2 p.m. in front of the Puck Building on the southeast corner of Houston and Lafayette Street, SoHo. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Fee: $10. Information: (718) 655-1883.

''NEW YEAR'S DAY HIKE.'' Explores the parks, shoreline and history of upper Manhattan. Meets Monday at noon at McDonald's on 181st Street and Broadway, Washington Heights. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Fee: $3; free for members. Information: (212) 663-2167.
